text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]v_1 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]v_2 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]v_3 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 2 \\ -1 \\ 4 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] be three vectors in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline].
Is the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] linearly independent? (You may need to do some row reduction.)
Does the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline]?
Is the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] a basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: We can answer these questions by row reducing the matrix with columns [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]v_3[/mathjaxinline]. If we do this row reduction, we obtain the [mathjaxinline]3\times 3[/mathjaxinline] identity matrix. This has a pivot in every column (i.e., no free variables), so the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent. In addition, it has a pivot in every row, so the list spans [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline]. Since both conditions hold, the list is a basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline].
